Solomon Northup.Action: Plays violin vigorously and skillfully at a social gathering, earning enthusiastic applause and personal thanks from attendees of a different race.
Plays the violin skillfully and confidently at a social gathering, earning enthusiastic applause and personal thanks from the attendees.
Looks admiringly at his family, gives children coins, kisses wife on the cheek, children giggle.
Smiles broadly and encourages wife to jump across the puddle.
Admiringly provides for and cares for his healthy, well-groomed family, showing responsibility and confidence in his role as a provider.
Encourages his wife Anne to jump across a muddy puddle with a broad smile and wave, demonstrating confidence and a calm, capable demeanor in everyday situations.
Encourages his wife Anne to jump into his arms, reassuring her warmly and catching her with delight, sharing a playful and affectionate moment with his family.
Encourages Anne to jump and confidently assures her he will catch her, then successfully catches her and sets her down lightly, delighting the children.
Engages politely and confidently with Mr. Cephas Parker in the store, demonstrating social ease and financial control by purchasing items for his family.
Expresses concern about the price of the carry all, showing cautiousness but also care for family resources.
Signs the condolence book and expresses sympathy for Mrs. Harrison and her children.
Addresses Jasper with a friendly warning to 'shop well, but mind your wallet.'
Cautiously inquires about the price of the carry all before purchase.
Politely engages in social niceties, signing the condolence book and expressing hope for better times.
Attempts to discuss price despite the shopkeeper's distraction, showing persistence and negotiation skill.
Responds politely to Fitzgerald's cold glare with 'No intrusion.'
Reads solemn news of the President's funeral to his children at the dinner table.
Reads solemn news from the newspaper to his children, demonstrating literacy and the ability to engage with current events thoughtfully.
Responds calmly and politely to Fitzgerald's cold glare and dismissive attitude without confrontation.
Does not challenge Fitzgerald's dismissive behavior or assert himself in the face of disrespect.
Compliments Margaret on her prayer, encourages children to learn violin, calms their dispute, and initiates family dinner.
Shares tender moment with Anne, showing physical and emotional closeness, holding her tightly and appreciating their children.
Calms down children arguing over violin lessons and organizes a plan for their first lesson after dinner.
Expresses appreciation for Margaret's prayer and encourages family harmony.
Engages warmly and lovingly with his family, showing emotional intelligence and confidence in his role as a father and husband.
Waves a hearty goodbye to his wife and children as they depart.
Engages politely with Mr. Moon and the two gentlemen introduced to him.
Lowers his eyes when speaking, indicating possible restraint or modesty.
Waves a hearty goodbye to his wife and children, showing calm and confidence in a moment of parting.
Engages in a polite and composed stroll, noticing and acknowledging people around him, indicating situational awareness.
Responds modestly to Mr. Moon's introduction about his violin skills, demonstrating humility and social grace.
Responds modestly and politely to compliments about his violin skills.
Engages thoughtfully in conversation with Brown and Hamilton about their entertainment company and their offer.
Considers the offer thoughtfully and shows desire to visit the metropolis, indicating openness and sincerity.
Decides not to send a letter to his wife despite having started writing it, showing possible emotional restraint or protective omission.
Plays violin to entertain others despite sparse audience, remains cool and abstains from drinking while others drink.
Responds to disappointment of others with understanding and a sober reflection on the national mood.
Laughs at the idea of joining the trip with Brown and Hamilton, showing lightheartedness and openness.
Abstains from drinking while others drink, remains cool and composed despite disappointment and poor reception.
Responds insightfully to the poor audience turnout by attributing it to the national mood, showing awareness of external factors.
Laughs at the idea of joining the circus trip, indicating a measured skepticism or cautiousness rather than impulsiveness.
Responds politely and with good humor to an invitation, considering a trial engagement despite family traveling soon.
Declines to obtain free papers despite advice and concern from others for his safety.
Considers a trial engagement with the circus despite family being away, showing openness to opportunity but cautious commitment.
Refuses to obtain free papers before entering slave states despite advice, potentially underestimating risks.
Reluctantly joins Hamilton and Brown in drinking a toast to the deceased President, showing respect and solidarity despite personal hesitation.
Expresses astonishment at receiving $43, more than his wages, showing awareness of his value and the situation.
Reluctantly joins in drinking to honor the deceased president, showing social awareness and respect for the moment.
Allows Brown and Hamilton to help him when violently ill, apologizes sincerely.
Lays in distress without complaint beyond apology, shows vulnerability.
Despite being violently ill and weak, he endures the physical distress and does not give up.
Apologizes weakly and shows vulnerability in front of others.
Does not take any visible action to improve his situation while ill, relying on others for care.
Fights desperately against his chains despite pain and exhaustion.
Calmly and clearly states his identity and free status to his captors.
Firmly asserts his identity and freedom despite intimidation and absence of proof.
Maintains quiet stoicism and refuses to admit false accusations under duress.
Insists on his freedom despite brutal beating, maintaining his dignity and truthfulness.
Insists he is a free man despite brutal physical punishment and extreme pain.
Remains silent and does not retaliate or argue beyond insisting his freedom, showing restraint under torture.
Does not attempt to escape or resist physically during the beating, possibly preserving strength and avoiding further harm.
Calls out for help repeatedly despite no response, showing persistence and vulnerability.
Despite exhaustion and despair, he struggles against his chains and calls out for help, refusing to passively accept his captivity.
Calls out for help but receives no response, indicating limited immediate effectiveness of his actions.
Takes some soap and rubs it over Randall, the cold and uncomfortable child.
Attempts to quiet Randall to spare him from a beating, showing concern for the child's suffering.
Takes the initiative to scrub the child Randall with soap, showing care and responsibility despite harsh conditions.
Attempts to calm the crying child by asking for quiet, showing some leadership and emotional control.
Has no answer to the child's question about his mother, indicating a moment of helplessness or lack of control over the situation.
Calms and reassures the distressed child Randall, promising his mother will come and urging him to be silent.
Politely thanks Radburn for the shirt despite its poor condition.
Refuses to give up his old shirt because it was from his wife, showing sentimental attachment.
Calms the distressed child Randall by promising his mother will come and urging silence, showing emotional control and presence of mind.
Refuses to eat the meager food offered, pushing the plate away, indicating possible despair or protest but also a lack of immediate practical acceptance of sustenance.
Insists on keeping his old shirt because it was from his wife, despite Radburn's insistence to take the new one, showing attachment but also a potential reluctance to adapt to circumstances.
Expresses belief in justice and freedom, insists on the crime of their situation, seeks a sympathetic ear to explain their plight.
Waits for a response from others but receives none, yet continues to try to reason and communicate.
Assumes good intentions of the men he journeyed with, calling them 'artists' and 'fellow performers' rather than kidnappers, despite uncertainty.
Attempts to apply reason to the situation and insists on the injustice of their captivity, expressing belief that they are free men and that their drink was altered.
Seeks a sympathetic ear and hopes that his traveling companions are making inquiries to help them.
Assumes with certainty that the two men who journeyed with him were not kidnappers but fellow performers, despite lacking proof.
Waits for a response from others but does not receive any, showing some hesitation or lack of assertiveness in rallying support.

Listens sympathetically to Eliza's lament, showing emotional intelligence and awareness of others' suffering.

Stares down Burch with silent rage, wishing bad things as a form of resistance.
Stares down Burch defiantly, wishing to exact revenge despite being powerless.
Recognizes his insignificance to his captors and the reality of his situation, which fuels his internal rage.
Listens carefully to Clemens Ray's advice about survival, understanding the need to conceal his identity and skills.
Shows a face of confused despair after hearing the harsh warning, indicating emotional struggle but not a lack of understanding.
Expresses desire to live rather than just survive, openly challenges Clemens Ray's fatalism, shows emotional agitation and sincerity.
Listens to Robert and Clemens Ray's discussion about fighting and survival, considers their perspectives thoughtfully.
Analyzes the situation and suggests that if well planned, the small crew could be overpowered.
Expresses frustration and agitation at Clemens Ray's defeatist attitude, asserting his desire to live rather than just survive.
Does not immediately dismiss the possibility of resistance despite the risks, showing confidence and resolve.
Does not take immediate action to organize a fight or escape, remaining in discussion phase.
Reacts with complete horror to Robert being stabbed.
Helps dump Robert's body overboard, showing respect for the deceased.

Helps Clemens Ray dump Robert's body overboard, calmly watches the body sink.
Is overwhelmed by the chaotic environment at the New Orleans port, showing initial disorientation.
Remains observant of the surroundings and the interactions between slave owners and captains, indicating situational awareness despite confusion.
Stands and watches as Clemens and Ray leave without offering aid or looking back.

Complies immediately with Freeman's order to stand up despite the hostile environment.

Observes the severe conditions of slavery with clear-eyed awareness and mental note of the systemic oppression.
Does not react impulsively or emotionally to the brutal scenes witnessed, maintaining composure.

Does not intervene or attempt to influence the sale or protect the family members from being separated despite witnessing their distress.

Follows Freeman's order to play the fiddle to drown out Eliza's cries, playing harder and more loudly.

Attempts to intervene to stop the white customer from beating Sam.

Enjoys the music and camaraderie with the Chickasaws and slaves, sharing in their respite and cultural exchange.
Quietly withdraws from the group to be alone by the river, appearing introspective and distant.

Expresses gratitude sincerely upon receiving a gift from Ford.
Shakes Eliza violently to stop her sobbing.

Receives a fiddle from Ford as a gift for his hard work and expresses gratitude, showing social awareness and adaptability.
Remains internally conflicted and uncertain about his altered state despite outward gratitude, indicating emotional complexity but some hesitation.
Snaps and violently shakes Eliza to stop her sobbing, an impulsive and harsh reaction under emotional stress.
Shakes Eliza violently to force her misery from her.
Urges Eliza to stop being overcome by sorrow and not drown in it.
Acknowledges his children as 'as my flesh' showing deep emotional connection.
Refuses to confront Master Ford or advocate for himself despite Eliza's urging.
